title: The Great Harlot
shortSummary: Revelation 17 reveals a vivid prophetic vision of the judgment of the great harlot, symbolizing a corrupt world system opposed to God. The chapter describes the woman’s relationship with a blasphemous beast, the political powers involved, and the ultimate victory of Christ over evil.
timeline: c. AD 95 - The Apostle John's vision on the island of Patmos

keyCharacters.name: The Apostle John
keyCharacters.description: The author and visionary who receives the revelation and describes the vision of the great harlot and the beast.

keyCharacters.name: One of the Seven Angels
keyCharacters.description: An angel who explains the mystery of the woman and the beast to John.

keyCharacters.name: The Great Harlot (Babylon the Great)
keyCharacters.description: A symbolic woman representing a corrupt, idolatrous, and persecuting world system that seduces kings and nations.

keyCharacters.name: The Beast
keyCharacters.description: A scarlet-colored beast with seven heads and ten horns, symbolizing a powerful, blasphemous political entity allied with the harlot.

definitions.definition: A biblical symbol for spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry, representing a corrupt system seducing nations away from God.
Symbolic of seven mountains and seven kings, representing political powers or kingdoms associated with the beast.
Symbolic of ten kings or rulers who will receive authority briefly and support the beast.
A prophetic title for the great city and corrupt system opposed to God, hidden in symbolism.
A place of imprisonment for evil spirits and demonic powers, from which the beast ascends.

outline.heading: Introduction to the Judgment of the Great Harlot
outline.description: John is invited by an angel to witness the judgment of the great harlot, described as a woman sitting on a scarlet beast, adorned with luxury but guilty of spiritual fornication and persecution of the saints.

outline.heading: Explanation of the Woman and the Beast
outline.description: The angel explains the symbolic meaning of the woman and the beast, identifying the beast’s seven heads as mountains and kings, and revealing the beast’s mysterious existence and ultimate destruction.

outline.heading: The Ten Horns and Their Alliance
outline.description: The ten horns represent ten kings who will briefly reign and unite in giving power to the beast, ultimately making war against the Lamb but being overcome by Him.

outline.heading: The Waters and the Doom of the Harlot
outline.description: The waters symbolize peoples and nations over which the harlot rules; the ten horns will turn against her, destroying her as part of God's sovereign plan, revealing her identity as the great city ruling over earthly kings.

application: Recognize the danger of spiritual compromise and idolatry in worldly systems and remain faithful to Christ alone.
Trust in the ultimate sovereignty of Jesus, the Lamb who overcomes all evil powers and will bring final judgment.
Be discerning of political and cultural alliances that oppose God’s kingdom and avoid being seduced by their promises.
Live as called, chosen, and faithful followers of Christ, confident in His victory over all opposition.

keyVerses.text: And upon her forehead was a name written, MYSTERY, BABYLON THE GREAT, THE MOTHER OF HARLOTS AND ABOMINATIONS OF THE EARTH.
keyVerses.significance: This verse identifies the woman as the symbolic representation of a corrupt and idolatrous world system opposed to God.

keyVerses.text: These shall make war with the Lamb, and the Lamb shall overcome them: for he is Lord of lords, and King of kings: and they that are with him are called, and chosen, and faithful.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms the ultimate victory of Christ over all evil powers and the assurance for believers who remain faithful.

keyVerses.text: And the woman which thou sawest is that great city, which reigneth over the kings of the earth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the identity of the harlot as a dominant worldly city or system exercising influence over earthly rulers.
